Neoproterozoic Banded Iron Formation (BIF) from Sawawin, NW Saudi Arabia and the Central Eastern Desert of Egypt define the 200 × 100 km Arabian-Nubian Shield (ANS) BIF basin. ANS BIF formed ∼750 Ma, prior to the Sturtian glacial episode (which began ∼716 Ma). BIF deposition occurred in a marine basin associated with arc/backarc basin volcanism and immature clastic sedimentation. Beds are composed of alternating iron- and silica-rich laminae, which may reflect seasonal changes in deposition of Fe vs. Si. Fe-rich layers are dominantly composed of primary fine-grained hematite “dust” and minor apatite, with abundant secondary magnetite. Rapid deposition is revealed by: (1) major and trace element data indicating that ANS-BIF are very pure (<20% detrital input) chemical sediments in spite of being deposited in a basin with high sedimentation rates, and (2) pervasive evidence for soft-sediment deformation, suggesting that rapid sedimentation of dense, weak materials resulted in slumping. Nd and Pb isotopic compositions are predominantly mantle-like, indicating the dominance of hydrothermal sources or weathering of juvenile ANS crust for these elements. REE data show HREE-enriched patterns typical of modern seawater, with small positive Eu and small negative Ce anomalies. Low abundances of transition elements that are commonly abundant in proximal hydrothermal deposits of modern oceans may indicate that ANS-BIF formed at some distance from hydrothermal vents, or may reflect prior sulfide scavenging by euxinic and sulfidic deep ocean waters. REE data and Zn/Co share characteristics of both modern seawater and hydrothermal vent fluids suggesting derivation from a mixture of shallow suboxic seawater with a dilute, low-T hydrothermal vent fluid. Considered in conjunction with BIF of similar age on other paleocontinents, these observations support that rapid and widespread re-oxygenation of Fe+2 in previously anoxic or suboxic seawater led to rapid precipitation of hematite “dust” and BIF deposition ∼750 Ma. Sulfate limitation or diminished bacterial sulfate reduction, required to form BIF instead of pyrite, may reflect large-scale glaciation but evidence for deep ferruginous conditions prior to Cryogenian glaciations suggests than any scenario that substantially reduced continental weathering (i.e., hard snowball or slushball) could have primed the oceans for BIF deposition. The likely short duration of ANS BIF deposition (a few to 10 s of kyr) and apparent timing well before the “Sturtian” glaciation suggest that conditions favoring Neoproterozoic BIF formation could have existed over an extended period (10 s of myrs) and that Neoproterozoic Oxidation Event began during the “Kaigas-Sturtian” time frame.

The origins of Archean and Paleoproterozoic BIF are largely nderstood. As commonly modeled, seafloor hydrothermal vents nd weathering of continental crust fed iron into the ocean. Because arly Earth’s environment was poor in O2 (Canfield, 2005), this iron as ferrous (Fe+2) and held in solution in the ocean. The developent and proliferation of photosynthetic cyanobacteria beginning n Archean time slowly increased oxygen in the oceans and the tmosphere (Kopp et al., 2005). Over time, soluble ferrous iron in eawater was oxidized to insoluble ferric iron, which precipitated o form sedimentary deposits of hematite (Fe2O3) and magnetite Fe3O4).
Originally the termination of BIF deposition at 1.8 Ga was interreted as when ferrous Fe had been completely oxidized in Earth’s cean, which then allowed dissolved and atmospheric oxygen levls to build to higher levels (Cloud, 1973; Holland, 1984; Kasting, 993). Secular studies of S isotopes (Canfield, 1998; Canfield and arquhar, 2009), allied with studies of redox-sensitive trace metals Mo, V: Scott et al., 2008; Shields-Zhou and Och, 2011), iron speciaion (Canfield et al., 2007, 2008), and Cr-isotopes (Frei et al., 2009), ow indicate that post 1.8 Ga deep oceans were likely still ferrugnous but largely sulfidic (euxinic). The apparent explanation for his deep ocean transition is related to an increased flux of sulfur, s sulfate (SO42−), delivered to surface oceans as a consequence f higher atmospheric oxygen concentrations and corresponding ncreased rates of oxidative weathering (Canfield, 1998). As a conequence of bacterial sulfate reduction (BSR), however, Earth’s deep cean reservoir now accumulated H2S at new levels and dissolved errous Fe is thought to have titrated out as pyrite instead of as xides.
The resumption of BIF deposition in Neoproterozoic time marks lesser, but second great episode of marine oxidation, within hat has recently been termed the Neoproterozoic Oxidation Event NOE; Shields-Zhou and Och, 2011). However, it is not clear how nd where oxygenation occurred (i.e., was it a whole-ocean pheomenon or limited to local chemocline-shelf margin interactions) nd whether the episodes recorded in various Neoproterozoic BIF eposits were synchronous and global or asynchronous and limited o isolated basins. Kirschvink (1992) inferred that the Neoproterooic anoxia/reoxygenation cycle and BIF deposition was a response o global Neoproterozoic glaciation, referred to as the “Snowball arth” hypothesis (Hoffman et al., 1998; Hoffman and Schrag, 002). During one or more Neoproterozoic ice ages, it is hypotheized that land and ocean surfaces were covered by thick ice sheets, hereby isolating seawater from the oxygen-rich atmosphere as ell as from riverine input of sulfate. Bacterial respiration, seafloor eathering, and hydrothermal activity consumed dissolved oxyen, making the ocean anoxic. Oceanic anoxia stabilized divalent, errous iron so that concentrations of Fe in Neoproterozoic seaater increased. When the ice melted, seawater re-equilibrated ith the oxygen-rich atmosphere, converting ferrous to ferric iron, hich precipitated as BIF. In recognition of the attractiveness of uch arguments, Hoffman (2007) identified the Neoproterozoic eappearance of BIF as one of five ‘key pillars’ that support the nowball Earth hypothesis.
It should be however, that the concept of a global freeze durng one or more Neoproterozoic “Snowball Earth” episodes and nferences about the extent of Neoproterozoic freezing are very ontroversial (e.g., Allen, 2007; Fairchild and Kennedy, 2007; Kerr, 000; Meert and VanderVoo, 1994; Peltier et al., 2007; Rieu et al., 007), calling into the question the validity of a glacial model or Neoproterozoic BIF. This controversy and the central role that eoproterozoic BIF plays in it have stimulated global study of hese deposits (Fig. 1A). One of the first alternatives to the conentional Snowball Earth hypothesis was by Hyde et al. (2000),

who presented a coupled climate ice-sheet model arguing that although the continents may have been covered during both the Sturtian and Marinoan glaciations, a substantial area of the equatorial oceans may have remained ice-free. Peltier et al. (2007) reinforced the alternative explanation, suggesting that negative feedbacks in the Neoproterozoic climate system were unlikely to allow global sea ice cover. The existence of such “slushball” solutions for Neoproterozoic glaciation has been further discussed on the basis of ice sheet coupled climate models in the papers of Liu and Peltier (2011) and Yang et al. (2012). This controversy regarding extent of ice cover and the central role that Neoproterozoic BIF plays in it have stimulated global study of these deposits (Fig. 1A), but non-glacigenic models ranging from localized hydrothermal activity associated with Rodinia breakup (Yeo, 1981; Eyles and Januszczak, 2004) to the metabolic activities iron-oxidizing photosynthetic bacteria (Le Heron et al., 2013) have also been proposed
Excellent examples of Neoproterozoic BIF are preserved in the Central Eastern Desert (CED) of Egypt (Sims and James, 1984; Stern et al., 2006; Basta et al., 2011; Khalil and El Shazly, 2012) and in the Midyan terrane of NW Saudi Arabia (Goldring, 1990) (Fig. 1B). These occurrences were once contiguous parts of a single BIF basin in the northern Arabian Nubian Shield (ANS) and are jointly referred to as ANS BIF (Fig. 1B and C). With the Red Sea closed, the ANS BIF basin occupies an area ∼200 × 100 km; Neoproterozoic deformation has modified the original basin geometry, and because much of this deformation involved shortening, the original basin must have been larger and defined a basin with a different outline in map view. ANS-BIF is especially significant because it is one of the few examples of Neoproterozic BIF where deposition was clearly associated in space and time with volcanic activity (Ilyin, 2009). Fourteen ANS BIF deposits are scattered throughout the Central Eastern Desert (CED) of Egypt (Basta et al., 2011), and a large and unusually well-preserved deposit is found along Wadi Sawawin in NW Saudi Arabia. Sawawin defines the NE margin of the ANS BIF basin and is the focus of this report.
This study reports new petrographic, geochemical, and Nd and Pb isotopic compositions of Neoproterozoic oxide facies ANS BIF. We also report data for two correlative Egyptian BIF deposits (Dabbagh and Kareim; Fig. 1C). We document the oxidation of an anoxic basin and discuss the implications of these data for understanding how ANS-BIF formed.
2. Geological background
BIF is abundant in the Wadi Sawawin area in northwestern Saudi Arabia (35◦45′–36◦E and 27◦50′ to 28◦N; Fig. 1B and C), about 50 km east of the Red Sea coast. The pertinent units (Fig. 2A and B) consist of Ghawjah Formation metavolcanic rocks overlain by metasedimentary rocks of the Silasia Formation. Both formations are part of the Za’am Group (Davies and Grainger, 1985; Johnson, 2004) and were metamorphosed to greenschist facies. Ghawjah metavolcanic rocks are mostly basalts and andesites with tholeiitic to calc-alkaline affinities. These erupted in an arc or back-arc basin and yield a U–Pb zircon age of 763 ± 25 Ma (Ali et al., 2010b). Ghawjah metavolcanic rocks are correlated with the “Younger Metavolcanic” rocks from the CED of Egypt, in terms of stratigraphic relations, chemical compositions, Nd-isotopic compositions, and U–Pb zircon ages (∼750 Ma; Ali et al. (2009)). In both areas, the metavolcanic sequence lies beneath BIF-bearing sedimentary rocks.
The BIF-bearing Silasia Formation (Bogue, 1953; Goldring, 1990) is a ∼1 km thick sequence of immature clastic metasedimentary rocks that locally contains tuffs, felsic flows, and dolerite sills. REE patterns for Sawawin BIF are strongly depleted in LREE and enriched in HREE relative to post Archean average shale (PAAS of Mclennan (1989); Fig. 6A). The presence or absence of a Eu anomaly is especially sensitive to hydrothermal inputs because Eu abundance in hydrothermal fluids is a function of solution temperature (Danielson et al., 1992). As a consequence, metalliferous sediments with strong hydrothermal inputs have large, positive Eu anomalies as measured by Eu/Eu*, where Eu = measured concentrations and Eu* indicates the concentration of Eu expected by interpolating from the abundances of adjacent REE. Examples of high Eu/Eu* indicating hydrothermal input is given by pre-2.7 Ga Algoma type (volcanic-hosted) BIFs that have Eu/Eu*∼1.5–2 (Kato et al., 2006). In contrast, mostly Paleoproterozoic Superior-type (sediment hosted) BIFs manifest a smaller to absent Eu anomaly (Eu/Eu*∼1; Kato et al. (2006)). ANS BIF have a negligible to slight Eu anomaly (Sawawin mean = 1.1 ± 0.1; Table 1 Fig. 6A and C), indicating that they do not represent proximal hydrothermal deposits but were probably generated by relatively cool hydrothermal solutions at some distance from their source vents. Our petrographic studies confirm that apatite controls P2O5 contents in Sawawin BIF. Apatite also contains abundant Ca but CaO does not strongly covary with P2O5 so inputs of Ca from other sources must be considered. Multiple sources for Ba are also evident based on microscopic observations showing that barite occurs as secondary grains close to veins in the Sawawin BIF (Fig. 4) as well as primary grains (detrital component). Barite is highly insoluble in oxic seawater and indicates the presence of dissolved sulfate in surface waters. Apatite is also primary as well as secondary. Apatite is an important biologic constituent (Baturin, 2003) that has been identified elsewhere in BIF as small (<100 nm) nanocrystals (Li et al., 2011) which could reflect variations in microbial influence in ANS-BIF. Petrographic observations identify no obvious biogenic features, but some spherules in the Sawawin BIFs may represent microbial activity; further discussion of what role life played in ANS BIF formation is beyond the scope of this paper. Alternatively, P could have been sorbed from seawater onto FeOOH and then released to form apatite during diagenesis. Studies that found that P co-precipitated from the non-buoyant part of a hydrothermal plume through the scavenging of the iron oxy-hydroxides particles (Baturin, 2003) are consistent with this interpretation, although the REE signatures do not indicate close proximity to a hydrothermal center.
5.3. How did ANS-BIF deposits form?
ANS BIF involves relatively pure chemical sediments but it is not clear if these are hydrothermal or hydrogenous deposits. The Fe-rich and Mn- and Al-poor composition of ANS BIF plots in the hydrothermal field of the (Bonatti et al., 1972) Al–Fe–Mn ternary diagram (Fig. 5A). Modern marine Fe-rich hydrothermal sediments show elevated concentrations of transition elements like Mn, Cu, Ni, Pb, Zn, and Co (Hein et al., 1994), but Sawawin BIF shows no correlation of those elements with iron. ANS BIF compositions are similar in some ways to modern marine ferromanganese crusts (Table 1; Hein et al., 1994), so these crusts may provide insights for understanding how ANS-BIF form. For example, ANS-BIF Fe-rich layers and those of other Neoproterozoic BIFs are compositionally similar to ironstone crusts (>15% Fe, non-banded, non-cherty sediment) recovered from Cretaceous Central Pacific seamounts (Table 1; Hein et al. (1994)). ANS-BIF differs from seamount ironstones, however, in containing significantly less V, Cr, Ni, Mo, and Zn. Toth (1980) advocated Co/Zn ratios to distinguish hydrothermal (averaging 0.15) vs. hydrogeneous (averaging 2.5) origins for trace metals incorporated into modern Mn and Fe-rich submarine oxide crusts. Sawawin BIF shows relatively high and variable Co/Zn (1.1 ± 2.), whereas the two CED BIF samples we analyzed are significantly lower (Co/Zn = 0.11 ± 0.4). Co/Zn for 14 samples from Egypt CED reported by Basta et al. (2011), however, are much higher than this, 4.6 ± 3 .0 (1 ), but this discrepancy could reflect the fact that we studied Fe-rich layers only whereas Basta et al. (2011) studied whole rock samples. On balance, Co/Zn distributions among all sampled ANS BIF localities seem to best support a significant hydrogenous contribution. sections.heading: 5.4. Implications of ANS BIF for understanding Neoproterozoic climate change
sections.text:
Four contrasting theories explain the global re-appearance of BIF in Neoproterozoic time: (1) the Snowball Earth Hypothesis (SEH) of Hoffman et al. (2002); (2) the Zipper Rift Model of Eyles and Januszczak (2004); (3) the Stagnant Basin model of Knoll et al. (1996); and (4) the Fall in Sea Level model of Kump and Seyfried (2005). The first calls on climate-driven redox changes in the global ocean, the second calls for local, tectonically controlled redox changes because of the restricted nature of rift basins, the third is controlled by ventilation of the ocean, which may or may not reflect climatic controls, and the fourth relies upon there having been a drastic (800 m or so) fall of sea level associated with Neoproterozoic continental glaciation, triggering a chemical reaction that led to BIF deposition. All scenarios for Cryogenian BIF formation require hydrothermal iron to have first accumulated while being segregated from major sources of oxidants. Widespread glacial scenarios, limiting input of sulfate and oxygen to oceans, conveniently provide such a mechanism. In addition, depressurization of midocean ridges associated with large (800 m or so) glacieustatic sea level falls, under such low seawater sulfate concentrations, should increase the flux of ferrous iron released from hydrothermal fluids (Kump and Seyfried, 2005). The latter effect would occur to varying degrees in either a hard or soft (slushball) scenario, but slushball Earth scenarios neither limit oxidation of surface seawater by mixing with the atmosphere nor provide a mechanism to limit photosynthetic biomass production, and subsequent H2S production (Fe titrant) associated with its decomposition by sulfate reduction.
“Sturtian” BIF successions variously occur below glacigenic strata (Chuos Formation, Otavi Group, northern Namibia – Le Heron et al., 2013), within glacigenic strata (Holowilena Ironstone, Flinders Ranges, South Australia – Le Heron et al., 2011; Numees Formation, Jakkalsberg member, South Africa – Macdonald et al., 2010; Rapitan, Canada), and near the top of glacial successions (Urucum District, Brazil – Urban et al., 1992; Trompette et al., 1998; Braemar facies, South Australia – Lottermoser and Ashley, 2000) and some “Sturtian” glacigenic deposits do not contain BIF at all (other compilations in Hoffman and Maloof, 2001; Eyles and Januszczak, 2004; Chumakov, 2008). This observation indicates that conditions for BIF deposition spanned multiple states of local glaciation, but a general association with glacigenic strata remains a typical characteristic among most Neoproterozoic BIF deposits. However, nearby ice may not have been required for Cryogenian BIF formation. Le Heron et al. (2011), in fact, recently describe iron formation definitively preceding the Chuos glaciation, and argue for non-glacially induced anoxia.
The age estimate of ∼750 Ma for ANS BIF and broadly similar ages among other BIFs (Macdonald et al., 2010b) are consistent with an interpretation that the “Sturtian” glacial episode was presaged by dramatic redox changes in the global ocean. ANS BIF may well have followed a glacial episode in the region, because ANS BIF overlies possibly glacial diamictite at Wadi Kareim. We note that there is no evidence at Sawawin or any other ANS-BIF locality for ice-transported detritus at the time of BIF formation.

. Conclusions
. ANS BIF is a chemical sediment consisting of iron-rich layers composed of hematite and magnetite alternating with silica-rich layers composed of cryptocrystalline quartz. Such lamination may be the product of seasonal variations in insolation, which in turn determines ice cover and/or biological activity. . ANS BIF was deposited ∼750 Ma, prior to the Sturtian (Cryogenian) glacial episode. . ANS-BIF is a rare example of Neoproterozoic ‘Algoma type’ BIF based on its intimate association with interbedded or underlying metavolcanic rocks and associated volcaniclastic sedimentary rocks. . ANS BIF was deposited in response to oxygenation of a marine

abstractText: Neoproterozoic Banded Iron Formation (BIF) from Sawawin, NW Saudi Arabia and the Central Eastern Desert of Egypt define the 200 × 100 km Arabian-Nubian Shield (ANS) BIF basin. ANS BIF formed ∼750 Ma, prior to the Sturtian glacial episode (which began ∼716 Ma). BIF deposition occurred in a marine basin associated with arc/backarc basin volcanism and immature clastic sedimentation. Beds are composed of alternating ironand silica-rich laminae, which may reflect seasonal changes in deposition of Fe vs. Si. Fe-rich layers are dominantly composed of primary fine-grained hematite “dust” and minor apatite, with abundant secondary magnetite. Rapid deposition is revealed by: (1) major and trace element data indicating that ANS-BIF are very pure (<20% detrital input) chemical sediments in spite of being deposited in a basin with high sedimentation rates, and (2) pervasive evidence for soft-sediment deformation, suggesting that rapid sedimentation of dense, weak materials resulted in slumping. Nd and Pb isotopic compositions are predominantly mantle-like, indicating the dominance of hydrothermal sources or weathering of juvenile ANS crust for these elements. REE data show HREE-enriched patterns typical of modern seawater, with small positive Eu and small negative Ce anomalies. Low abundances of transition elements that are commonly abundant in proximal hydrothermal deposits of modern oceans may indicate that ANS-BIF formed at some distance from hydrothermal vents, or may reflect prior sulfide scavenging by euxinic and sulfidic deep ocean waters. REE data and Zn/Co share characteristics of both modern seawater and hydrothermal vent fluids suggesting derivation from a mixture of shallow suboxic seawater with a dilute, low-T hydrothermal vent fluid. Considered in conjunction with BIF of similar age on other paleocontinents, these observations support that rapid and widespread re-oxygenation of Fe+2 in previously anoxic or suboxic seawater led to rapid precipitation of hematite “dust” and BIF deposition ∼750 Ma. Sulfate limitation or diminished bacterial sulfate reduction, required to form BIF instead of pyrite, may reflect large-scale glaciation but evidence for deep ferruginous conditions prior to Cryogenian glaciations suggests than any scenario that substantially reduced continental weathering (i.e., hard snowball or slushball) could have primed the oceans for BIF deposition. The likely short duration of ANS BIF deposition (a few to 10 s of kyr) and apparent timing well before the “Sturtian” glaciation suggest that conditions favoring Neoproterozoic BIF formation could have existed over an extended period (10 s of myrs) and that Neoproterozoic Oxidation Event began during the “Kaigas-Sturtian” time frame. © 2013 Elsevier B.V.
